name: Washington
description: Washington established the first U.S. cabinet, appointing secretaries to advise on national affairs.

name: Washington
description: Washington signed the Residence Act, designating a new capital site along the Potomac River.

name: Washington
description: Washington approved the Bill of Rights, adding ten amendments to the Constitution.

name: Washington
description: Washington signed the Coinage Act, establishing the U.S. Mint for national currency.

name: Washington
description: Washington declared U.S. neutrality in the French Revolutionary Wars, avoiding European conflict.

name: Washington
description: Washington led troops to suppress the Whiskey Rebellion, affirming federal authority.

name: Washington
description: Washington signed the Jay Treaty, improving trade relations with Britain despite controversy.

name: Washington
description: Washington delivered his Farewell Address, warning against political factions and foreign alliances.

name: J. Adams
description: Adams navigated the XYZ Affair, exposing French demands for bribes in peace talks.

name: J. Adams
description: Adams signed the Alien and Sedition Acts, aiming to protect national security amid French tensions.

name: J. Adams
description: Adams appointed envoys to France, defusing tensions and avoiding war.

name: J. Adams
description: Adams oversaw the move of the federal government to the new capital, Washington, D.C.

name: Jefferson
description: Jefferson reduced federal spending, cutting taxes and military budgets to promote simplicity.

name: Jefferson
description: Jefferson established the U.S. Military Academy at West Point for officer training.

name: Jefferson
description: Jefferson secured the Louisiana Purchase, doubling U.S. territory for $15 million.

name: Jefferson
description: Jefferson sent Lewis and Clark to explore the Louisiana Territory, mapping the West.

name: Jefferson
description: Jefferson negotiated peace with Tripoli, ending the First Barbary War.

name: Jefferson
description: Jefferson signed the Non-Importation Act, restricting British goods to pressure trade policies.

name: Jefferson
description: Jefferson enacted the Embargo Act, halting U.S. exports to avoid European wars.

name: Jefferson
description: Jefferson supported the ban on importing enslaved people, effective January 1, 1808.

name: Madison
description: Madison repealed the Embargo Act, replacing it with the Non-Intercourse Act to ease trade tensions.

name: Madison
description: Madison annexed West Florida, claiming it as part of the Louisiana Purchase.

name: Madison
description: Madison authorized the charter of the First Bank of the United States to expire, opposing centralized banking.

name: Madison
description: Madison led the U.S. into the War of 1812 against Britain over trade and impressment issues.

name: Madison
description: Madison supported the invasion of Canada, though U.S. forces faced setbacks in the war.

name: Madison
description: Madison fled Washington as British troops burned the capital during the War of 1812.

name: Madison
description: Madison celebrated the Treaty of Ghent, ending the War of 1812 with no territorial changes.

name: Madison
description: Madison signed a bill creating the Second Bank of the United States to stabilize the economy.

name: Monroe
description: Monroe initiated the First Seminole War, sending troops to pursue Seminoles in Florida.

name: Monroe
description: Monroe negotiated the Anglo-American Convention, setting the U.S.-Canada border at the 49th parallel.

name: Monroe
description: Monroe acquired Florida from Spain via the Adams-Onís Treaty, expanding U.S. territory.

name: Monroe
description: Monroe signed the Missouri Compromise, balancing slave and free states in Congress.

name: Monroe
description: Monroe welcomed Missouri as a slave state, implementing the Missouri Compromise.

name: Monroe
description: Monroe recognized new Latin American republics, supporting their independence from Spain.

name: Monroe
description: Monroe issued the Monroe Doctrine, warning Europe against colonizing the Americas.

name: Monroe
description: Monroe hosted Lafayette’s U.S. tour, celebrating the Revolutionary War hero’s return.

name: J.Q. Adams
description: Adams proposed internal improvements, like roads and canals, to boost national infrastructure.

name: J.Q. Adams
description: Adams attended the Panama Congress, fostering diplomatic ties with Latin America.

name: J.Q. Adams
description: Adams negotiated a trade treaty with Britain, easing tensions over commerce.

name: J.Q. Adams
description: Adams signed the Tariff of 1828, raising duties but sparking Southern opposition.

name: Jackson
description: Jackson introduced the spoils system, rewarding loyal supporters with government jobs.

name: Jackson
description: Jackson signed the Indian Removal Act, authorizing forced relocation of Native tribes.

name: Jackson
description: Jackson reorganized the cabinet after the Petticoat Affair strained political alliances.

name: Jackson
description: Jackson vetoed the recharter of the Second Bank of the United States, weakening centralized banking.

name: Jackson
description: Jackson issued the Force Bill, authorizing military action to enforce tariffs in South Carolina.

name: Jackson
description: Jackson faced censure by the Senate over his bank veto, escalating political tensions.

name: Jackson
description: Jackson paid off the national debt, the only time in U.S. history.

name: Jackson
description: Jackson recognized Texas independence, though annexation was delayed until 1845.

name: Van Buren
description: Van Buren faced the Panic of 1837, addressing the economic crisis with limited federal action.

name: Van Buren
description: Van Buren oversaw the Trail of Tears, enforcing Cherokee removal to Oklahoma.

name: Van Buren
description: Van Buren negotiated the Aroostook War truce, avoiding conflict with Britain over Maine’s border.

name: Van Buren
description: Van Buren established the Independent Treasury System to manage federal funds.

name: W.H. Harrison
description: Harrison delivered a lengthy inaugural address, but died of pneumonia after one month.

name: Tyler
description: Tyler assumed the presidency after Harrison’s death, establishing the precedent for vice-presidential succession.

name: Tyler
description: Tyler signed the Webster-Ashburton Treaty, resolving U.S.-Canada border disputes.

name: Tyler
description: Tyler pursued annexation of Texas, though Congress initially rejected the treaty.

name: Tyler
description: Tyler signed a treaty with China, opening trade ports and expanding U.S. commerce.

name: Polk
description: Polk annexed Texas, admitting it as a state despite Mexican objections.

name: Polk
description: Polk signed the Oregon Treaty, securing the Pacific Northwest up to the 49th parallel.

name: Polk
description: Polk led the Mexican-American War, capturing key territories including California.

name: Polk
description: Polk signed the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, ending the Mexican-American War with vast land gains.

name: Taylor
description: Taylor supported California’s statehood as a free state, intensifying slavery debates.

name: Taylor
description: Taylor died of illness, unable to resolve the Compromise of 1850 debates.

name: Fillmore
description: Fillmore signed the Compromise of 1850, balancing slave and free state interests.

name: Fillmore
description: Fillmore enforced the Fugitive Slave Act, sparking Northern resistance.

name: Fillmore
description: Fillmore sent Commodore Perry to Japan, initiating trade negotiations.

name: Pierce
description: Pierce supported the Gadsden Purchase, acquiring land from Mexico for a railroad.

name: Pierce
description: Pierce signed the Kansas-Nebraska Act, escalating tensions over slavery’s expansion.

name: Pierce
description: Pierce faced Bleeding Kansas violence, struggling to maintain national unity.

name: Pierce
description: Pierce recognized the pro-slavery Kansas government, alienating Northern supporters.

name: Buchanan
description: Buchanan endorsed the Dred Scott decision, denying citizenship to enslaved people.

name: Buchanan
description: Buchanan negotiated the English Bill, attempting to admit Kansas as a slave state.

name: Buchanan
description: Buchanan faced the Panic of 1857, offering limited federal relief for economic woes.

name: Buchanan
description: Buchanan failed to prevent Southern secession after Lincoln’s election.

name: Lincoln
description: Lincoln called for volunteers to suppress the Southern rebellion after Fort Sumter’s fall.

name: Lincoln
description: Lincoln issued the preliminary Emancipation Proclamation, redefining the war’s purpose.

name: Lincoln
description: Lincoln delivered the Gettysburg Address, emphasizing national unity and freedom.

name: Lincoln
description: Lincoln supported the 13th Amendment, aiming to abolish slavery permanently.

name: Lincoln
description: Lincoln was assassinated, leaving Reconstruction to his successor, Andrew Johnson.

name: Johnson
description: Johnson began Reconstruction, issuing pardons to former Confederates.

name: Johnson
description: Johnson vetoed the Civil Rights Act, but Congress overrode to protect freedmen’s rights.

name: Johnson
description: Johnson purchased Alaska from Russia, expanding U.S. territory.

name: Johnson
description: Johnson faced impeachment over Tenure of Office Act violations, narrowly avoiding removal.

name: Grant
description: Grant established the Board of Indian Commissioners to reform Native American policy.

name: Grant
description: Grant signed the 15th Amendment, guaranteeing voting rights regardless of race.

name: Grant
description: Grant enforced the Ku Klux Klan Act, suppressing Southern violence against freedmen.

name: Grant
description: Grant created Yellowstone as the first national park, preserving natural heritage.

name: Grant
description: Grant faced the Panic of 1873, struggling to stabilize the economy.

name: Grant
description: Grant signed the Civil Rights Act of 1875, aiming to protect public accommodations.

name: Grant
description: Grant supported the Resumption Act, returning the U.S. to the gold standard.

name: Grant
description: Grant attended the Centennial Exposition, celebrating America’s 100th anniversary.

name: Hayes
description: Hayes ended Reconstruction, withdrawing federal troops from the South.

name: Hayes
description: Hayes signed the Bland-Allison Act, mandating silver coinage despite his veto.

name: Hayes
description: Hayes vetoed Chinese immigration restrictions, upholding treaty obligations.

name: Hayes
description: Hayes hosted the first White House Easter Egg Roll, starting a tradition.

name: Garfield
description: Garfield advocated civil service reform before his assassination after six months.

name: Arthur
description: Arthur assumed the presidency, committing to continue Garfield’s reform agenda.

name: Arthur
description: Arthur signed the Chinese Exclusion Act, restricting immigration for a decade.

name: Arthur
description: Arthur signed the Pendleton Act, establishing merit-based civil service hiring.

name: Arthur
description: Arthur dedicated the Washington Monument, completing a national landmark.

name: Cleveland
description: Cleveland vetoed fraudulent pension bills, protecting federal funds from misuse.

name: Cleveland
description: Cleveland dedicated the Statue of Liberty, accepting France’s gift to America.

name: Cleveland
description: Cleveland signed the Interstate Commerce Act, regulating railroads for fair practices.

name: Cleveland
description: Cleveland pushed for tariff reduction, though Congress blocked his efforts.

name: B. Harrison
description: Harrison signed the Sherman Antitrust Act, curbing monopolies in business.

name: B. Harrison
description: Harrison approved the McKinley Tariff, raising duties to protect U.S. industries.

name: B. Harrison
description: Harrison created the first U.S. forest reserves, preserving natural resources.

name: B. Harrison
description: Harrison opened Ellis Island, streamlining immigration processing.

name: Cleveland
description: Cleveland repealed the Sherman Silver Purchase Act, stabilizing the gold standard.

name: Cleveland
description: Cleveland sent troops to break the Pullman Strike, restoring rail service.

name: Cleveland
description: Cleveland invoked the Monroe Doctrine, mediating a Venezuela-Britain border dispute.

name: Cleveland
description: Cleveland maintained neutrality during the Cuban revolt, avoiding intervention.

name: McKinley
description: McKinley signed the Dingley Tariff, raising rates to protect American businesses.

name: McKinley
description: McKinley led the U.S. to victory in the Spanish-American War, gaining territories.

name: McKinley
description: McKinley issued the Open Door Policy, promoting equal trade in China.

name: McKinley
description: McKinley signed the Gold Standard Act, fixing U.S. currency to gold.

name: McKinley
description: McKinley was assassinated, leaving Roosevelt to pursue his policies.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: Roosevelt assumed the presidency, promising to continue McKinley’s policies.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: Roosevelt mediated the Coal Strike, securing better wages for miners.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: Roosevelt supported Panama’s independence, securing the Panama Canal Zone.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: Roosevelt issued the Roosevelt Corollary, asserting U.S. influence in Latin America.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: Roosevelt brokered the Treaty of Portsmouth, ending the Russo-Japanese War.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: Roosevelt signed the Pure Food and Drug Act, protecting consumer health.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: Roosevelt sent the Great White Fleet on a world tour, showcasing naval power.

name: T. Roosevelt
description: Roosevelt expanded national forests, conserving millions of acres.

name: Taft
description: Taft pursued dollar diplomacy, promoting U.S. investments abroad.

name: Taft
description: Taft established the U.S. Postal Savings System, aiding small savers.

name: Taft
description: Taft broke up the Standard Oil monopoly, enforcing antitrust laws.

name: Taft
description: Taft created the Children’s Bureau, addressing child welfare issues.

name: Wilson
description: Wilson signed the Federal Reserve Act, creating a central banking system.

name: Wilson
description: Wilson enacted the Clayton Antitrust Act, strengthening anti-monopoly laws.

name: Wilson
description: Wilson maintained neutrality as World War I escalated in Europe.

name: Wilson
description: Wilson signed the Keating-Owen Act, restricting child labor.

name: Wilson
description: Wilson led the U.S. into World War I, declaring war on Germany.

name: Wilson
description: Wilson proposed the Fourteen Points, outlining a vision for post-war peace.

name: Wilson
description: Wilson championed the League of Nations, though the U.S. didn’t join.

name: Wilson
description: Wilson supported the 19th Amendment, granting women the right to vote.

name: Harding
description: Harding signed the Budget and Accounting Act, modernizing federal budgeting.

name: Harding
description: Harding signed the Fordney-McCumber Tariff, raising duties to protect industries.

name: Harding
description: Harding died, leaving scandals like Teapot Dome to tarnish his legacy.

name: Coolidge
description: Coolidge assumed the presidency, restoring trust after Harding’s scandals.

name: Coolidge
description: Coolidge signed the Immigration Act, limiting arrivals from certain countries.

name: Coolidge
description: Coolidge signed the Revenue Act, cutting taxes to stimulate the economy.

name: Coolidge
description: Coolidge supported the Air Commerce Act, regulating aviation safety.

name: Coolidge
description: Coolidge vetoed farm relief bills, prioritizing limited government.

name: Coolidge
description: Coolidge signed the Kellogg-Briand Pact, aiming to outlaw war.

name: Hoover
description: Hoover faced the stock market crash, initiating the Great Depression.

name: Hoover
description: Hoover signed the Smoot-Hawley Tariff, raising duties but worsening trade.

name: Hoover
description: Hoover created the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to aid struggling businesses.

name: Hoover
description: Hoover dispatched troops to disperse the Bonus Army, sparking public criticism.

name: FDR
description: FDR launched the New Deal, creating jobs through programs like the CCC.

name: FDR
description: FDR signed the Securities Exchange Act, regulating Wall Street.

name: FDR
description: FDR signed the Social Security Act, establishing a safety net for retirees.

name: FDR
description: FDR won re-election, expanding New Deal programs to combat the Depression.

name: FDR
description: FDR proposed court-packing, attempting to reform the Supreme Court.

name: FDR
description: FDR signed the Fair Labor Standards Act, setting minimum wages and hours.

name: FDR
description: FDR maintained neutrality as World War II began in Europe.

name: FDR
description: FDR signed the Selective Service Act, preparing for potential war.

name: FDR
description: FDR delivered the Four Freedoms speech, articulating democratic ideals.

name: FDR
description: FDR authorized Japanese-American internment after Pearl Harbor’s attack.

name: FDR
description: FDR met with Allied leaders at Tehran, planning D-Day’s invasion.

name: FDR
description: FDR signed the GI Bill, aiding veterans with education and housing.

name: FDR
description: FDR died, leaving Truman to conclude World War II.
